title: I Visited Every Boutique Steel Factory at Taipei Cycle Show – Daniel Yang
content:
Amid the sea of aluminum and carbon manufacturers at Taipei Cycle Show, Daniel Yang went searching for something different — the steel factories keeping metal bikes alive…

The Taipei Cycle Show is chaotic, colorful, and overwhelming — three massive halls packed with brands, components, manufacturers, and suppliers. Thanks to its location and manufacturing expertise, Taipei draws people from every cycling market: Asia, Europe, Australia, and the Americas.

While companies proudly display their latest products in their polished booths, the real work happens in backroom meetings with customers, suppliers, and old friends.

Amid the sea of carbon and aluminum open model designs, I set out to visit every boutique steel factory I could find. Unlike carbon and aluminum, steel doesn’t rely on expensive molds or high-volume production. Steel invites creativity, allowing nuance, craftsmanship, and personality to show through. When I came up with the idea for this article, I worried there wouldn’t be enough stories to tell. I was wrong: every factory had an authentic story to tell and a unique strength.

Manufacturing in 60 Seconds

If you’ve ever wondered how bikes go from idea to production, here’s a quick breakdown:

  • Open Model — The factory designs the product, and any brand can put its logo on it. There is no exclusivity.
  • Original Design Manufacturer (ODM) — A collaboration between the factory and the brand. The brand provides a rough design, and the factory helps bring it to market. There is a spectrum of how much engineering each side does. Generally, the designs are exclusive.
  • Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) — The brand provides all the drawings, specifications, and tooling, and the factory is responsible for production or, in many cases, a sub-assembly. This is how most large brands operate.

The lines between these categories can blur, but that’s the general framework.

For example, most of Innova Tire’s business is OEM for large tire brands. The tires on display are not actually for sale; they are open models: off-the-shelf designs where you pick the compound, casing, and graphics. If you want something different, like a 32” XC tire, you can even hand them a napkin sketch, and they’ll bring it to life.

“The reason why we make open business mold is because we believe everyone got their good ideas, and we welcome everyone to make good tires together, under their brand.” — Tony “The Tire Guy” Hsieh, Innova GM

Open models and ODM may seem like shortcuts, but they often allow small brands to get started. They offer a solid foundation and access to decades of institutional knowledge.

Tonjin: Beautiful Design

Tonjin was founded 20 years ago by Bill Chi to focus specifically on high-end steel frame design. While other factories chase volume, Tonjin leans into creativity, specializing in fillet brazing and complex design challenges.

The open-model steel cargo e-bike on display exemplifies their work. By itself, it is already a complex design, but on closer inspection, you see the unique bends and joints that fluidly integrate the electromechanical components and set Tonjin apart.

In particular, the joint at the headtube and rack mount — fillet brazed and filed smooth — is done simply for its beauty. As a framebuilder, a one-off cargo bike with this much design detail is already impressive, but to be able to mass-produce it is on another level.

Over the last few years, particularly after the pandemic, Tonjin has diversified, taking on more OEM aluminum frame projects and medical devices. Still, their passion for steel bikes hasn’t faded:

“In the future, we think the general steel bike [market will] not grow very big, but the niche steel market will always remain. The famous brands will always do limited handmade steel frame productions, which will inspire more people to ride and produce steel bikes. One of our brands we work with has a chromoly cargo bike, and it makes me happy to know that they ride this bike every day, get married, take their kids to new experiences, to do happy things on a bike.” — Johnny Chi (founder’s son)

ORA: High Technology

ORA Engineering is the most high-tech steel manufacturer at the show. Their booth is a reflection of their work: professional, flawless, and modern. Despite the contemporary appearance, ORA is almost 30 years old, founded by Jim Hsu. Over the decades, they have steadily expanded their capabilities and in-house knowledge.

ORA is best known for their titanium frames, but they bring the same meticulous approach to steel. What sets them apart is their in-house butting. They import unique raw materials, like 630 stainless steel from the USA, and develop their own tubing using secret forming recipes. This gives them control over quality and opens the door to creative tube profiles, like their eccentric and asymmetric butting.

By revenue, titanium leads. But by volume, steel is still their most popular material. Their business is roughly evenly split across titanium, steel, and aluminum. Like many factories in this article, their business model has evolved: twenty years ago, OEM dominated their work. Today, 70% of their production is ODM, working closely with smaller brands.

“We like working with small brands because they are more creative and have more interesting designs. More challenging for ORA. We feel steel has soul, and we see it in our customers who work with us. It makes us happy to see their success.” — Emily Yu

As you can tell, ORA has a polished, professional presence. But behind that is a thoughtful, woman-led team — a rarity in the Western bike industry.

Side Quest: How Hard Is It To Find a Stem?

The real reason I came to the Taipei Cycle Show wasn’t for frames — it was to find a stem supplier for my Artefact road and gravel bikes. I was searching for an open model with simple, clean lines that would complement the skinny round tubes of steel and titanium bikes.

How hard could it be?

 

 

Cockpit suppliers like Zoom, Kalloy, and TranzX make millions of stems per year, yet they only brought their latest e-bike and internally routed stems to the show. Every stem on display was Cybertruck-chic: big, bold, and boxy. They didn’t understand why I was there. To be fair, neither did I.

Tucked away in the corner of the trade show, I stumbled across a small Taiwanese component company: Chuhn-E Industries Co., Ltd. Hidden beneath cute, albeit outdated, aardvark decals was exactly what I was searching for — a high quality, simple, round-body stem with beautiful fillet-brazed-esque transitions to the clamps.

According to Ken, who turned out to be the founder’s son, this stem was developed 10 years ago as a lightweight, simple, high-performance open model — exactly what I traveled all the way to Taipei to find.

I also learned that Chuhn-E was a small, family-owned and operated business. Like the steel factories I visited, Chuhn-E reminded me that catalogs and websites don’t tell the full story. Culture, history, and craft don’t always come through in a product photo. You have to be there in person to see and feel it.

Lung Yang: The Artisan

Lung Yang might be the smallest steel factory at the show, but they still manage to produce over ten thousand frames each year. Founded 40 years ago by Peter Hung, Lung Yang has always prioritized quality and relationships over volume.

“Some of our customers, like Cinelli, have been with us for over 10 years, and we have become good partners. Same with our high-end BMX companies. Now we are also working with smaller, newer brands.” – Steven Hung

The welds on their raw frames were some of the best I saw at the entire show. No paint to hide mistakes — just clean, confident work on full display.

What I didn’t expect to find at the booth was a fully modern steel, Pinion gearbox-equipped, belt-drive, full-suspension frame built in collaboration with Stevie from Ride Stoke. A true mixture of modern design and traditional craftsmanship. According to Lung Yang, the prototype took over two weeks to build by hand, but with production tooling, they estimate it will only take eight hours. This is a great example of ODM at play: Stevie designs the frame, Lung Yang figures out the tooling and manufacturing.

The steel business has remained stable, thanks to long-term partnerships. Many of their clients are high-end BMX companies who won’t give up 4130 any time soon.

When asked about the future of steel bikes, Steven, the founder’s son, gave me the classic Taiwanese shrug:

“Chà bu duō” (about the same).

For Lung Yang, that seems just fine.

Maxway: Old Reliable

Maxway has been making steel bikes for 39 years. In the fast-paced world of consumer goods, you must evolve to survive. They began as a welding subcontractor during the ’80s BMX boom. In the ’80s and ’90s, they produced up to 30,000 frames per month. Now, they produce around 30,000 per year.

When people think of high-end steel road bikes, they often think of Italy. However, this Taiwanese factory builds some of the finest mass-produced steel road bikes on the market. The journey from department store bikes to a high-end steel factory took decades.

Twenty years ago, most of their work was OEM. Today, 60% is ODM for smaller brands. Although smaller brands can be more work, Maxway enjoys working with them more because they find the people behind the brands more interesting and passionate.

“We think the future of steel is its environmental impact. Every year, this becomes a more important topic. Steel is durable, repairable, and recyclable. But for us, as a factory, steel produces very little waste. All the cutoffs and chips are recycled, and cutting oil is filtered and reused. When we remodeled part of our factory, we even repurposed the steel beams to build racks to store our frames.” – Allen Chiuu, R&D

Maxway was founded by YiYi and Meg, a brother and sister team. Now Allen and Angel, YiYi’s kids, bring fresh energy to the booth.

Steel Has Soul

All the steel factories at the show have been around for decades. To survive that long, especially in an industry that has moved on to carbon and aluminum, you need to bring something unique to the table.

For Tonjin, it’s their blend of complex design and aesthetics. For ORA, it’s their engineering and progressive culture. For Lung Yang, it’s their artisanal craft. For Maxway, it’s their ability to deliver quality at scale (and their quirkiness).

As an engineer, I never fully bought into the “steel is real” mantra. All materials can be made into great bikes. But after spending time with these factories and hearing their stories, I realized the soul of steel isn’t really about the material — it’s about the people.

Producing a steel bike with one of these factories is a collaboration. The creativity of the brand, the knowledge of the factory, the skills of the craftsmen, the pride in the work, and the culture of the people all contribute to the final product. When all those things align, you don’t just get a bike — you get a bike with soul.
